  • Alfred Francis Newton
Flohria subcoerulea (LeConte), a relictual genus and species of the subtribe Philonthina (tribe Staphylinini) from the Americas, is redescribed and illustrated, its distribution documented, and lectotypes designated. The phylogenetic position of the genus within Philonthina, as well as its potential age and origin, is discussed.

Projects

Projects (2)
Taxonomic Catalog of the Brazilian Fauna - Staphylinidae (Coleoptera)
Project
Taxonomic Catalog of the Brazilian Fauna. This is the first product of the effort of more than 500 zoologists, experts in many different groups of animals that inhabit the Brazilian territory. To date, 116,356 valid species are known to Brazil, its huge majority of arthropods (about 85% with almost 94,000 species!). For Staphylinidae (Coleoptera) the researchers Alfred F. Newton and Edilson Caron have been listed 2.812 valid species in 471 genera and 16 subfamilies. The great advantage of this project is the dynamic to allows additions and corrections in real time, inclusion of newly discovered species, corrections associated with nomenclatural decisions, distribution expansion, among others. Hopefully soon, this site will provide the very latest on the taxonomic knowledge of Brazilian species.
View
  • 1 Update
Beetles in deep time and more
Project
1. Fossil Beetles. Mesozoic beetles (Coleoptera) from the Middle Jurassic Daohugou biota (ca. 165 Ma), the Early Cretaceous Jehol biota (ca. 125 Ma) of northeastern China and the mid-Cretaceous Burmese amber (ca. 99 Ma): Systematics, phylogeny, biogeography and palaeoethology. Studied groups include Archostemata (Ommatidae), Myxophaga (Hydroscaphidae) and the hyper-diverse Polyphaga (Derodontidae, Jacobsoniidae, Silphidae, Smicripidae, Staphylinidae, Tetratomidae, etc.); 2. Subsocial Behavior in Fossil Insects. Early evolution of parental care in Mesozoic carrion beetles (Silphidae); 3. Palaeobiota in Amber. Morphology, systematics, biogeography and complex behavior of insects in Cretaceous Burmese amber
